sn15.6:1.2: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha … and asked him,
sn15.6:1.5: It’s not easy to calculate how many years, how many hundreds or thousands or hundreds of thousands of years it lasts.”
sn15.6:2.1: “But sir, is it possible to give a simile?”
sn15.6:2.3: “Suppose there was an iron citadel, a league long, a league wide, and a league high, full of mustard seeds pressed into balls.
sn15.6:2.4: And as each century passed someone would remove a single mustard seed.
sn15.6:2.5: By this means the huge heap of mustard seeds would be used up before the eon comes to an end.
sn15.6:2.6: That’s how long an eon is.
sn15.6:2.7: And we’ve transmigrated through many such eons, many hundreds, many thousands, many hundreds of thousands.
sn15.6:2.9: This transmigration has no known beginning. …
sn15.6:2.10: This is quite enough for you to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding all conditions.”
